## Overview

An implementation of Paul Tol's colour schemes, ready for each type of data, with colours that are distinct for all people, including colour-blind readers. This package provides tools to simulate colour-blindness and to test how well the colours are identifiable. Several thematic palettes (geologic timescale, land cover, FAO soils, etc.) are also implemented for use with `graphics` or `ggplot2`.

## Installation

Install the released version of `khroma` from CRAN:

```{r cran-installation, eval = FALSE}
install.packages("khroma")
```

Or install the development version from GitHub with:

```{r gh-installation, eval = FALSE}
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("nfrerebeau/khroma")
```

## Usage
### Paul Tol's Colour Schemes

Paul Tol offers carefully chosen schemes, ready for each type of data, with colours that are:

* Distinct for all people, including colour-blind readers.
* Distinct from black and white.
* Distinct on screen and paper.
* Matching well together.

All the scales presented in Paul Tol's technical note [^1] are implemented here, for use with `graphics` or `ggplot2`.

#### Qualitative data

```{r tol-qualitative, echo=FALSE, fig.height=2, fig.width=7, fig.align="center"}
# Qualitative data
plot_scheme(colour("bright")(7))
plot_scheme(colour("contrast")(3))
plot_scheme(colour("vibrant")(7))
plot_scheme(colour("muted")(9))
```

#### Diverging data

```{r tol-diverging, echo=FALSE, fig.height=2, fig.width=7, fig.align="center"}
# Diverging data
plot_scheme(colour("BuRd")(9))
plot_scheme(colour("PRGn")(9))
plot_scheme(colour("sunset")(11))
```

#### Sequential data

```{r tol-sequential, echo=FALSE, fig.height=2, fig.width=7, fig.align="center"}
# Sequential data
plot_scheme(colour("YlOrBr")(9))
plot_scheme(colour("iridescent")(23))
plot_scheme(colour("smooth rainbow")(34))
```

### Scientific colour schemes

The following scientific colour schemes are available:

* International Chronostratigraphic Chart.
* AVHRR Global Land Cover Classification.
* FAO Soil Reference Groups.

More will be added in future releases (suggestions are welcome).

### Diagnostic tools

Test how well the colours are identifiable (*bright* colour scheme):

```{r diagnostic, echo=FALSE, fig.height=2, fig.width=7, fig.align="center"}
plot_map(colour("bright")(7))
```

Simulate colour-blindness (*bright* colour scheme; from left to right and from top to bottom: deuteranopia, protanopia, tritanopia and achromatopsia):

```{r anomalize, echo=FALSE, fig.height=7, fig.width=7, fig.align="center"}
palette <- colour("bright")
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
scales::show_col(convert(palette, mode = "deuteranopia")(7))
scales::show_col(convert(palette, mode = "protanopia")(7))
scales::show_col(convert(palette, mode = "tritanopia")(7))
scales::show_col(convert(palette, mode = "achromatopsia")(7))
```

[^1]: Tol, Paul (2018). *Colour Schemes*. SRON. Technical Note No. SRON/EPS/TN/09-002. URL: <https://personal.sron.nl/~pault/data/colourschemes.pdf>.
